path_1.title: Mask of Zorro, The (1998)
path_1.feeling: Classic swashbuckling charm, fun but light compared to the character-driven dramas I love.

path_1.title: Jungle Book, The (1994)
path_1.feeling: Pleasant family adventure, though the family focus keeps it from resonating deeply for me.

path_1.title: Fantasia (1940)
path_1.feeling: I appreciate the artistry, but animation and musical fantasia aren’t my usual go-to.

path_1.title: Field of Dreams (1989)
path_1.feeling: Earnest and poignant with just enough magic to work on me.

path_1.title: Devil Wears Prada, The (2006)
path_1.feeling: Sharp and entertaining workplace dramedy, if a bit airy for my taste.

path_1.title: Misérables, Les (1998)
path_1.feeling: Powerful, morally rich drama that hits all my favorite notes.

path_1.title: I Am Not Your Negro (2017)
path_1.feeling: Thoughtful, affecting documentary that engages my interest in history and justice.

path_1.title: Red Violin, The (Violon rouge, Le) (1998)
path_1.feeling: Elegant, globe-spanning drama with history and mystery that I gravitate toward.

path_1.title: Birds, The (1963)
path_1.feeling: Hitchcock’s slow-burn dread still thrills me.

path_1.title: American in Paris, An (1951)
path_1.feeling: Charming but the musical romance doesn’t fully grab me.

path_1.title: Absolute Power (1997)
path_1.feeling: A solid political-tinged thriller with stakes I enjoy.

path_1.title: In Love and War (1996)
path_1.feeling: Wartime romance with enough heart and history to pull me in.

path_1.title: Arrival (2016)
path_1.feeling: Intelligent, humane sci-fi right in my wheelhouse.

path_1.title: Atomic Blonde (2017)
path_1.feeling: Stylish and kinetic, but the action-forward approach leaves me cooler.

path_1.title: I Am Not Your Negro (2017)
path_1.feeling: A sobering, incisive reflection that I find compelling.

path_1.title: Fantasia (1940)
path_1.feeling: Visually lush, yet the musical vignettes keep me at a distance.

path_1.title: Winter's Tale (2014)
path_1.feeling: Overwrought mystical romance isn’t my thing.

path_1.title: Colette (2018)
path_1.feeling: Smart, literary biopic with the historical texture I enjoy.

path_1.title: Frozen (2013)
path_1.feeling: Catchy and cute, but animated musicals rarely rise above pleasant for me.

path_1.title: Jesus Camp (2006)
path_1.feeling: Fascinating and unsettling look at American faith and politics.

path_1.title: Godfather, The (1972)
path_1.feeling: Grand, character-driven crime saga that largely aligns with my tastes.

path_1.title: Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring, The (2001)
path_1.feeling: Sweeping and engaging, though high fantasy isn’t my top draw.

path_1.title: France (2021)
path_1.feeling: Media satire and drama intrigue me, even if it’s a bit cool and cerebral.

path_1.title: Absence of Malice (1981)
path_1.feeling: Ethical journalism drama is squarely in my lane.

path_1.title: Lion King, The (1994)
path_1.feeling: Simple, serviceable family tale, but it feels generic and thin.

path_1.title: Kramer vs. Kramer (1979)
path_1.feeling: Intimate, emotionally honest drama that I tend to value highly.

path_1.title: Captain Phillips (2013)
path_1.feeling: Tense true-story thriller with moral weight I appreciate.

path_1.title: Thirteen Days (2000)
path_1.feeling: Absorbing historical crisis piece that fits my interests.

path_1.title: Revolutionary Road (2008)
path_1.feeling: Well-acted, bleak relationship drama that I respect more than I love.

path_2.title: Mask of Zorro, The (1998)
path_2.feeling: Enjoyed the dashing swashbuckling and mentor‑to‑hero arc without needing deeper weight.

path_2.title: Jungle Book, The (1994)
path_2.feeling: A pleasant romp with earnest heart, more charming than profound.

path_2.title: Fantasia (1940)
path_2.feeling: Enchanted by the bold marriage of classical music and imagery.

path_2.title: Field of Dreams (1989)
path_2.feeling: Moved by its gentle faith, reconciliation, and whisper of wonder.

path_2.title: Devil Wears Prada, The (2006)
path_2.feeling: Entertained by brisk wit and the tug between ambition and integrity.

path_2.title: Misérables, Les (1998)
path_2.feeling: Swept up by grace, justice, and the ferocity of conscience.

path_2.title: I Am Not Your Negro (2017)
path_2.feeling: Stirred and sobered by Baldwin’s piercing moral clarity.

path_2.title: Red Violin, The (Violon rouge, Le) (1998)
path_2.feeling: Captivated by the instrument’s haunting journey and the lives it touches.

path_2.title: Birds, The (1963)
path_2.feeling: Chilled anew by relentless dread and unnerving ambiguity.

path_2.title: American in Paris, An (1951)
path_2.feeling: Enjoyed the charm and craft, though the romance felt airy.

path_2.title: Absolute Power (1997)
path_2.feeling: Gripped by the cat‑and‑mouse and the corrosion of power.

path_2.title: In Love and War (1996)
path_2.feeling: Touched by tender, doomed romance amid formative scars.

path_2.title: Arrival (2016)
path_2.feeling: Absorbed by thoughtful communication and the ache of choice.

path_2.title: Atomic Blonde (2017)
path_2.feeling: Admired the icy atmosphere and craft but kept at an emotional distance.

path_2.title: I Am Not Your Negro (2017)
path_2.feeling: Stirred and sobered by Baldwin’s piercing moral clarity.

path_2.feeling: Enchanted by the bold marriage of classical music and imagery.

path_2.title: Winter's Tale (2014)
path_2.feeling: Put off by syrupy mysticism and forced sentiment.

path_2.title: Colette (2018)
path_2.feeling: Engaged by a woman claiming her voice against stifling convention.

path_2.title: Frozen (2013)
path_2.feeling: Enjoyed the sisterly bond and buoyant tunes, if a bit over‑polished.

path_2.title: Jesus Camp (2006)
path_2.feeling: Uneasy and reflective watching fervor shape young minds.

path_2.title: Godfather, The (1972)
path_2.feeling: Riveted by operatic morality, loyalty, and the cost of power.

path_2.feeling: Swept up by fellowship, purpose, and mythic stakes.

path_2.title: France (2021)

path_2.feeling: Provoked to weigh press freedom against personal harm.

path_2.title: Lion King, The (1994)
path_2.feeling: A decent fable of responsibility that lands more as lesson than revelation.

path_2.title: Kramer vs. Kramer (1979)
path_2.feeling: Deeply moved by hard‑won tenderness and parental growth.

path_2.title: Captain Phillips (2013)
path_2.feeling: Tense, empathetic, and respectful of steady competence under fire.

path_2.title: Thirteen Days (2000)
path_2.feeling: Engrossed by sober brinkmanship and the discipline of restraint.

path_2.title: Revolutionary Road (2008)
path_2.feeling: Impressed by the performances while bruised by its bleak domestic spiral.

path_2.feeling: Entertained by spirited swashbuckling, though the stakes felt pleasantly light.

path_2.title: Jungle Book, The (1994)

path_2.title: Birds, The (1963)

path_2.feeling: Appreciated the craft, though the romance and musical flourishes kept me at a distance.

path_2.feeling: Caught up in the conspiracy, even if the polish outpaces plausibility.

path_2.feeling: Affected by tender affection tested by duty and time.

path_2.title: Arrival (2016)
path_2.feeling: Stirred by language, time, and empathy braided into quiet suspense.

path_2.title: Atomic Blonde (2017)
path_2.feeling: Enjoyed the Cold War style and sting, though its heart stays frosty.

path_2.title: I Am Not Your Negro (2017)
path_2.feeling: Shaken by its clear-eyed reckoning and moral urgency.

path_2.feeling: Impressed by the symphonic spectacle, less engaged by its episodic drift.

path_2.title: Colette (2018)
path_2.feeling: Invigorated by a voice claiming its authorship against stifling convention.

path_2.feeling: Pleasantly warmed by sisterly devotion, even if the beats feel familiar.

path_3.title: Mask of Zorro, The (1998)
path_3.feeling: Swashbuckling fun with old-school charm, more grin than depth for me.

path_3.title: Jungle Book, The (1994)
path_3.feeling: Pleasant jungle adventure with a sweet heart, but it never truly swept me away.

path_3.title: Fantasia (1940)
path_3.feeling: A dazzling audiovisual curio I admired more than I emotionally felt.

path_3.title: Field of Dreams (1989)
path_3.feeling: Earnest, nostalgic magic that hit my sentimental side despite the corn.

path_3.title: Devil Wears Prada, The (2006)
path_3.feeling: Sharp, breezy workplace sparring I enjoyed without loving.

path_3.title: Misérables, Les (1998)
path_3.feeling: A stirring, humane epic whose moral weight and emotion floored me.

path_3.title: I Am Not Your Negro (2017)
path_3.feeling: Incisive, eloquent, and bracing—its clarity and pain stayed with me.

path_3.title: Red Violin, The (Violon rouge, Le) (1998)
path_3.feeling: Elegant, time-spanning intrigue with a melancholic beauty I savored.

path_3.title: Birds, The (1963)
path_3.feeling: Primal, relentless dread crafted with such precision I was riveted.

path_3.title: American in Paris, An (1951)
path_3.feeling: Charming in fits, though the gloss and musical whimsy kept me at arm’s length.

path_3.title: Absolute Power (1997)
path_3.feeling: Satisfying, cynical thriller—engaging if a touch contrived.

path_3.title: In Love and War (1996)
path_3.feeling: Tender and bittersweet, its wartime longing worked on me.

path_3.title: Arrival (2016)
path_3.feeling: Quietly profound and absorbing, its human core resonated.

path_3.title: Atomic Blonde (2017)
path_3.feeling: Stylish, bruising spy craft I liked more for mood than substance.

path_3.title: I Am Not Your Negro (2017)
path_3.feeling: Powerful, lucid testimony that echoed long after.

path_3.title: Fantasia (1940)
path_3.feeling: Impressive orchestral imagery I respected more than I connected with.

path_3.title: Winter's Tale (2014)
path_3.feeling: Sweeping romantic mysticism that left me cold and unconvinced.

path_3.title: Colette (2018)
path_3.feeling: A lively, incisive portrait of authorship and autonomy I found engaging.

path_3.title: Frozen (2013)
path_3.feeling: Winsome and tuneful, charming even if it didn’t fully sweep me away.

path_3.title: Jesus Camp (2006)
path_3.feeling: Chilling and revealing—its portrait of zeal unsettled me.

path_3.title: Godfather, The (1972)
path_3.feeling: Majestic, inexorable tragedy that gripped me from first to last.

path_3.title: Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring, The (2001)
path_3.feeling: Grand, absorbing questcraft that stirred me more in spirit than awe.

path_3.title: France (2021)
path_3.feeling: A cool, prickly media satire that intrigued me more than it moved me.

path_3.title: Absence of Malice (1981)
path_3.feeling: Absorbing ethics-in-journalism drama with stakes that tightened nicely.

path_3.title: Lion King, The (1994)
path_3.feeling: Simple, serviceable fable whose lesson landed but left me underwhelmed.

path_3.title: Kramer vs. Kramer (1979)
path_3.feeling: Intimate, humane heartbreak that felt honestly earned.

path_3.title: Captain Phillips (2013)
path_3.feeling: Tense, procedural survival that kept me clenched and invested.

path_3.title: Thirteen Days (2000)
path_3.feeling: Clear, gripping crisis management that scratched my historical itch.

path_3.title: Revolutionary Road (2008)
path_3.feeling: Handsomer than happy, a bruising portrait of dreams curdling.

path_3.title: Mask of Zorro, The (1998)
path_3.feeling: A rousing, old-fashioned swashbuckler whose charm and momentum kept me smiling.

path_3.title: Jungle Book, The (1994)
path_3.feeling: Lush, earnest adventure where nature’s wonder charmed me more than the romance.

path_3.title: Fantasia (1940)
path_3.feeling: A sumptuous audiovisual experiment I admired more than I loved.

path_3.title: Field of Dreams (1989)
path_3.feeling: Gentle, wistful magic about fathers and memory that quietly got to me.

path_3.title: Devil Wears Prada, The (2006)
path_3.feeling: Slick, brisk workplace satire carried by icy charisma more than depth, but I enjoyed the ride.

path_3.title: Misérables, Les (1998)
path_3.feeling: A sweeping, compassionate redemption tale that stirred me deeply.

path_3.title: I Am Not Your Negro (2017)
path_3.feeling: A piercing, eloquent essay that sharpened history into urgent moral clarity.

path_3.title: Red Violin, The (Violon rouge, Le) (1998)
path_3.feeling: An elegant, time-spanning lament where craft and fate intertwined hauntingly.

path_3.title: Birds, The (1963)
path_3.feeling: Primal, escalating dread staged with icy control that thrilled and unsettled me.

path_3.title: American in Paris, An (1951)
path_3.feeling: Lavish and charming in moments, but the glossy spectacle kept me at a distance.

path_3.title: Absolute Power (1997)
path_3.feeling: Sturdy, old-school intrigue that entertained me more than it moved me.

path_3.title: In Love and War (1996)
path_3.feeling: Handsome, earnest romance whose wartime ache landed for me.

path_3.title: Arrival (2016)
path_3.feeling: Thoughtful, humane sci‑fi whose linguistic puzzle and quiet emotion resonated.

path_3.title: Atomic Blonde (2017)
path_3.feeling: Icy, stylish spycraft whose bruising set pieces impressed me more than the heart.

path_3.title: I Am Not Your Negro (2017)
path_3.feeling: Incisive, impassioned collage that made history feel immediate and inescapable.

path_3.title: Fantasia (1940)
path_3.feeling: Dazzling orchestral imagery I respected, even if it left me emotionally cool.

path_3.title: Winter's Tale (2014)
path_3.feeling: A mawkish, muddled fable whose celestial swooning left me cold.

path_3.title: Colette (2018)
path_3.feeling: A lively, incisive portrait of authorship and agency that engaged me.

path_3.title: Frozen (2013)
path_3.feeling: Bright, heartfelt pop fairy tale whose sisterhood warmed me even as the songs wore thin.

path_3.title: Jesus Camp (2006)
path_3.feeling: A chilling, revealing look at indoctrination that left me uneasy and alert.

path_3.title: Godfather, The (1972)
path_3.feeling: A majestic, mournful crime saga whose family and power currents swept me up.

path_3.title: Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring, The (2001)
path_3.feeling: A grand, immersive quest where camaraderie and stakes carried me more than the fantasy trappings.

path_3.title: France (2021)
path_3.feeling: A cool, prickly media satire whose ideas intrigued me more than it moved me.

path_3.title: Absence of Malice (1981)
path_3.feeling: A thoughtful, morally knotty newsroom drama that satisfied me.

path_3.title: Lion King, The (1994)
path_3.feeling: Derivative, didactic animation whose lesson landed but the magic didn’t.

path_3.title: Kramer vs. Kramer (1979)
path_3.feeling: A tender, unsentimental portrait of parenthood that quietly floored me.

path_3.title: Captain Phillips (2013)
path_3.feeling: A taut, empathetic real-world thriller that kept me clenched.

path_3.title: Thirteen Days (2000)
path_3.feeling: Absorbing, procedural brinkmanship whose moral stakes kept me riveted.

path_3.title: Revolutionary Road (2008)
path_3.feeling: A handsome, caustic suburban tragedy that left a lingering hollow ache.

path_3.title: Mask of Zorro, The (1998)
path_3.feeling: A breezy, swashbuckling mentorship that kept me smiling more than stirred.

path_3.title: Jungle Book, The (1994)
path_3.feeling: Handsome, straightforward adventure whose charm outpaced its depth.

path_3.title: Fantasia (1940)
path_3.feeling: A sumptuous sight-and-sound tapestry I admired more than I felt.

path_3.title: Field of Dreams (1989)
path_3.feeling: An earnest, quietly magical father-son ache that snuck up on me.
